snippet: Economic gains in many sectors have yet to solve the problem of feeding the world. In Africa alone, government policies and fertilizer costs are inhibiting agricultural progress.
abstract: Tyler Cowen Economic View column contends drought-induced run-up in corn prices is a reminder that the problem of world hunger is nowhere near solved; holds price surge, third major international food price spike in last five years, belies the assumption that widespread economic development leads to corresponding gains in agriculture; argues in Africa, government policies and fertilizer costs are inhibiting agricultural progress.
lead_paragraph: Economic gains in many sectors have yet to solve the problem of feeding the world. In Africa alone, government policies and fertilizer costs are inhibiting agricultural progress.

headline.print_headline: World Hunger: The Problem Left Behind
headline.seo: World Hunger, the Problem Left Behind - Economic View
headline.main: World Hunger: The Problem Left Behind
